abstract.p: Allen Cichanski letter comments on July 15 article on unread best sellers

block.p: Your article about unread best sellers (Arts & Ideas pages, July 15) immediately brought to mind the time when I was chairman of a search committee for a new academic department head.

At one of our evaluation committee meetings everyone expressed how greatly they were impressed by the publication record of one of the applicants. When I asked what I thought was an innocent question, ''Which of his papers did you find most interesting and impressive?'', I was met with stony silence. Not one member of the committee had read even one of the papers.
Your article about unread best sellers (Arts & Ideas pages, July 15) immediately brought to mind the time when I was chairman of a search committee for a new academic department head.

At one of our evaluation committee meetings everyone expressed how greatly they were impressed by the publication record of one of the applicants. When I asked what I thought was an innocent question, ''Which of his papers did you find most interesting and impressive?'', I was met with stony silence. Not one member of the committee had read even one of the papers.
I now realize that like unread best sellers, most academic publications are valued only for filling resumes and curriculums vitae and for bragging about, not actually being read.
The writer is professor of geology and geography, Eastern Michigan University.
